reviews.text: As stated above this property is beautiful and convient to the National Park. The place was packed with tours...the lodge was back to back people arriving and departing at frequent intervals. Our room was very very small. Though we are not handicapped, we were given a hadicapped room. Can imagine fitting a wheel chair or walker in there, except in the bathroom. The ramp into the shower and extra space to move a wheelchair around evidently took the place of a closet. Was shocked to find no place to hang clothing....not even a hook for a wet jacket!
reviews.title: Beautiful Property with Small Rooms

reviews.text: Date of stay: Tuesday, June 26, 2012 through Thursday, June 28 2012
reviews.title: Won't stay again & wouldn't book trip with Princess

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This was our family trip for the summer so a lot of the booking and reservations were done online using tripadvisor as my assistance - specifically ask for the "caribou wing" - this is what we did & we were pleased with our lodging. I think this was the newest wing and we had air conditioning. Our trip was not your typical "princess cruise" it was a road trip - we rented a car in Fairbanks and drove to Kenai stopping in Denali and Anchorage.
reviews.title: Fantastic Views and Rustic Living

reviews.text: Prior to going this lodge I had read the reviews within tripadvisor and they were mixed, but since it was considered a "Princess" lodge we figured we would give it a try. During our visit to Alaska we stayed at three "Princess" lodges (Denali, McKinley & Kenai) with Kenai being our last.
reviews.title: Skip this one and you will be much happier!!
Great location and friendly service
reviews.text: My BIGGEST disappointment with this location was the customer service regarding the day trips . I had reserved a day trip for our family for the 11-12 hour round trip to Kantashna through reservedenali.com. The itinerary they emailed me stated we needed to meet at Denali Main Lodge entrance at 7:00 am. We were there by 7:00 am along with a multitude of other Princess Lodge guests awaiting their buses to take them on this excursion or others that were occurring that day. We were unsure of which bus to take so we approach a princess travel assistant named Steve Fisher. He was so flippant with me when I asked him a question about the buses. He specifically asked me if I had some sort of document princess prints out for their guests to aid in their travel itinerary. He specifically used the term "it's your lifeline" and when I did not have this document he promptly turned around and left me standing there in pure disbelief. I still cannot believe that a person that is hired to aid in customer service handled this situation so poorly. Yes, I did not have the "lifeline" I needed but he could have taken a couple of moments to help me out - I was after all a guest within the princess lodge and maybe a potential future cruise line customer.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Compared to all the other Princess Lodges (Kenai, McKinley and Fairbanks) this is by far the biggest complex with many individual accommodation blocks on site. The huge number of tourists that come through this place could be daunting if you prefer more relaxed quiet accommodation. However having said that it suited our needs for the 2 nights that we were there. We ate in the Bar Grill a much cheaper option than the highly priced Dining Restaurant. There are also numerous gift shops, cafes etc across the road which cater for the tourist trade quite well. One thing that did annoy us was the noisy adjoining room's shower and toilet. The walls are paper thin so beware! If you have an early tour get up it could act as your alarm back up however, otherwise it can be rather annoying if you want a sleep in after a full day's activity! Everything else is what you would expect and were were pleased without raving about it. Compared to the more sedate Princess Kenai River Lodge this operation is huge! Organisation and Information re tours was OK and freely available!
reviews.title: Huge Lodge! Large Numbers of People!
Poor Communications All Around
reviews.text: Despite making reservations for my family of three, we were put in a room with one king bed and a fold out couch. Had to call front desk to request sheets and pillows which were dropped off at the room. Housekeeping did not ask if I wanted them to make up the bed. This request and the folded out couch bed, however, did not clue them in that there were 3 people in this room. Consequently, I had to call each of the three nights we were there to obtain an extra set of towels.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Front desk lied to me, saying they were fully booked. I noticed a sign along the highway in front of the hotel that night saying "Rooms Available Tonight".
reviews.title: Nice lodge, poor tour organization

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Remember: Alaska is a rain forest which means it rains. We are in the middle of our Princess land tour. Got in from the Princess Mt. McKinely lodge after a painfully slow 2 1/2 hour bus ride. Rooms, however, were ready and we were able to get our room overlooking the mountains in Block 10 on the second floor. The lodge is newer than the McKinely one and really beautiful. The room had all the amenities, although it did resemble a Motel 6 in the lower 48. Since we got a good price on the cruise and landtour, the lodge is a good value. Food is expensive and not included. Worst however is the poor organization of the land tour operation. We had a free afternoon yesterday--Princess wanted you to book overprices land excursions. In order not to take business away, Princess does not provide any information about Denali National Park. There is a free shuttle bus service to the park entrance. From there you can hike, take tours, go to 2 information centers with free films and of course the free dog show. The following morning we had to get up at 6 for a boring 4 hour park historic tour: saw nothing but rain. Were done at 10. Rooms, however, have to be vacated at 11. Our train is not till 4pm. We are sitting in the lobby for 6 hours doing nothing. Each day is poorly organized. A big problem is the luggage: it has to be out way before you are doing anything. This trip is great for older travelers or people who have difficulty walking and/or carrying their own luggage. That said: you could never see that part of Alaska for the less money. If you want to see that part of Alaska without spending a fortune, you have to bite the frozen salmon
reviews.title: Entry Point for Denali National Park
Motel 6 level
reviews.text: Staying at the Princess Denali Lodge for one night was included in the land portion of a cruise tour. After an enjoyable train ride from Whittier, we arrived at our room in the early evening, although it was hard to tell with 20 hours of sunlight. The grounds of the lodge are very compact with all buildings within a short walk; however, there is also a shuttle that circles the complex. The main lodge is very impressive, as are the log buildings and grounds, and has many design elements of those in the National Parks. On a river with views of the mountains, the site is ideal for a short stay. The room, although clean, would be the equivalent of a motel in the two-star range with rustic furnishings and inexpensive fixtures. We attended a dinner performance of Music of Denali with the six performers also functioning as waiters. The boarding house setting included salad, biscuits, fish, ribs, potatoes, vegetables, drink and cobbler, which was quite filling but had a bland taste. The actors/singers were excellent and the plot revealed the details of the first party to climb Mt. McKinley. The quality of the songs, like most productions, contained both winners and at least one turkey. The Natural History Tour was included and consisted of busing 17 miles into Denali Park with stops for a film, a ranger presentation at a cabin and an Indian talk, which blended the past and present. Of course, the animals that were sighted highlighted the excursion. Be prepared for an assault by mosquitoes. For breakfast, we had pastries/cereal at the main lodge and for lunch, a well-made pizza at a restaurant next to the lodge. Across the street is a strip of businesses including restaurants. We enjoyed our 20 hours at the Denali Lodge and could certainly recommend the experience for future travelers.

The lodge is more like a city within it's self. Room was nice, clean and fairly quiet considering how many people were staying there. The food was good at the restaurant altough it was really loud. We were impressed with the way Princess has everything organized for travelers on these tours.
reviews.title: Nice time-nice place

reviews.text: Overall this was a good destination for us - convenient for our tour, the services were good, grounds were neat and well maintained. This is by no means a luxury hotel (but you are not going to find a 4 star hotel nearby anyway) but the rooms were neat and clean, the beds comfortable. No air conditioning in the rooms but it really wasn't necessary (rooms cooled off pretty quickly with the fans and temps got down to the low 50's at night so sleeping was very comfortable) and this was despite our daytime temps getting into the low 80's, well above normal. Restaurants were a little expensive (but again so was everything else - you are in Denali, pretty much in the middle of nowhere so they have a captive audience). We used a coupon from Alaska Tour Savers that brought our price for two nights down to $170 which was far more in line with what I think the hotel was worth. Net net it worked out well and we would consider using it again.
reviews.title: Worked out well

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed here after and Alaskan Princess Cruise. Was somewhat relieved to find that this place was not as bad as the McKinley Lodge. The rooms were OK but a bit dated and our room was much closer to the main lodge. It was situated near other shops and restaurants so we did not feel like we were isolated. Would have liked to stay longer in Denali to take advantage of the wonderful shuttle service and free trips available at the National Park. Unfortunately our itinerary was filled with tours booked through Princess. The Music of Denali show was quite entertaining and the food was OK. My husband is a vegetarian and was told that he would be catered for. Turned out not to be true and he had to make a meal of the salad, mashed potatoes, peas and corn. (not very good value for him) The rest of us had delicious salmon and ribs to accompany our vegies!
reviews.title: Wasn't as bad as we expected
Depressing
reviews.text: Overall we found that the Princess land tour was a bit disappointing. At times very disorganized and people were always losing their luggage. Also the transfers were badly timed resulting with us having to leave the accommodation very early and then spend way too many hours stranded at an airport. When we enquired about catching a later bus they told us there wasn't one but we found out that there was one (it would be bringing our friends lost luggage) but it was fully booked. (would have been nicer if they told us the truth!)

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This place is just as depressing as the Mt Mckinley Princess Lodge. Can't say we are looking forward to Fairbanks! The room is even darker and just does not feel clean! Food dreadful. At least the view is good. Do not even bother with The Music of Denali show, it's like an amateurish school production.
reviews.title: Denali princess wilderness lodge

reviews.text: We enjoyed our stay as it was the best of the 3 Princess properties we stayed at (other 2 were Fairbanks and McKinley). Room was clean and the property had the best selection of restaurants and activities. Wished the wi-fi was in each room though. Nice views of the Nenana river and the east boundary of Denali National Park. We enjoyed staying here.
reviews.title: Best of the Princess Properties.

reviews.text: This is a pretty amazing Hotel. The surrounding town is comprised of the hotel and about 10 shops, across the street. The Hotel itself is really 12 buildings in which you can reside in. They have trams to help you navigate the little community of the hotel, but I can't see you needing one. The Lobby is wonderful, with speedy internet connection for no price, and occupied with comfortable couches and chairs for your free time. The rooms were much better then the Fairbanks Hotels, resembling something you would see at a Holiday Inn, despite the older television.
reviews.title: Dream Hotel

reviews.text: Was on a Princess cruise to Alaska. This hotel was part of the land tour. Denali is breathtaking. Our view from the room was a sight to see and so was the room. Upon entering the room you could smell something.. There was so much dust in the room we had to keep the doors open for a hour to air it out. It was only a night stay but that one night was terrible. We had a 10 1/2 train ride in and expected more. No soap, shampoo nothing just a layer of dust and stink. The Italian restaurant had a good pizza but was still rocking from train and boat ride. Lots of souvenir shops across the street prices are good.
reviews.title: Denali Princess hotel

reviews.text: This would have been a great experience if Princess Cruise Lines would have not been so greedy. There were so many people, the place reminded me of a busy ant hill. Food in a restaurant was impossible because of the crowds. The pizza we had in our room was ok, but we really wanted a nice dining experience and not just pepperoni.
reviews.title: Too Many People

reviews.text: We had 3 singles traveling together so we required 2 beds & a roll-away. We did have to call for the roll-away to be brought to the room, but it cam quickly. With just a slight movement of a bench there was plenty of room for the roll-away.
reviews.title: Rooms are nice, property layout odd
